reviewText: Your very traditional point-and-click adventure game with goofy characters, pun-based humor, and passable storylines. The whole is greater than the sum of its parts. If you like point-and-click adventure games that are light-hearted and fairly well-polished with your typical point-and-click puzzle elements, then it is hard to go wrong with any Sam & Max game. These are really terrific to throw on a low-powered laptop and play while you're watching television or waiting at the airport or otherwise needing some simple distraction.

reviewText:
This series is FANTASTIC. I have played the other Telltale Games and even the original Sam & Max, and I adore this series. This first season is the weakest entry in the series, (with Devil's Playhouse contrastly being one of the best adventure games out there), but the series gets better and better with each episode. However, this does have a hard time running on Windows 10, and there is no patch for it from Telltale. If you don't feel like fixing the first two seasons yourself, at least go buy Season 3.

From the excellent writing to the likable characters to the award-winning music to the excellent voice acting - including Roger Jackson of Powderpuff Girls and Scream fame - you can't miss this series. I love it, and a potential Season 4 is my most wanted sequel in gaming, (since Psychonauts 2 just got funded).

EDIT: There IS a way to easily fix this on your Windows 10 computers! What you need to do is this...

(credit to Kong)

The following is working for me with Season 2 on Windows 10:

Open the files folder for the game on your harddrive.
Backup prefs.prop and all .save files.
Delete those files from game folder.

Run REGEDIT
Go to HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Telltale Games\Sam & Max Season 2
Modify Windowed from 0 to 1

Run game. It should now be running windowed!
I had to play through one episode in a very compressed Windows mode, but by the next I was playing at full screen again!

If you want full screen, follow this guide...

Step 1 : You need to download and install Notepad++ from the following link:
https://notepad-plus-plus.org/download/

(NOTE - Didn't need to download Notepad, I had it already).

Step 2 : Open up your Steam folder, by default it's in 'C:\program files (x86)\steam'. in the Steam folder you must go to '\steamapps\common' and there you must look for the 'sam and max' folders with the season and episode number behind it. Here you must open up the folder of one of the episodes that won't work for you.

Step 3 : You might want to copy the 'prefs.prop' to a save place in case you break something in the next steps, but this is not required if you know what you are doing.

Step 4 : Open the 'prefs.prop' for the Sam&Max episode that doesn't work for you by right clicking the file and selecting 'Edit with Notepad++' (or edit normally)

Step 5 : The file opened will look unreadable at first and you must scroll the bar to the right to find the word 'Windowed' followed by the number 0. You could also use the Search option inside Notepad++ to locate this word. Now you only have to change the 0 to 1 and save the file. (In case there is no 'Windowed' in the file, rightclick the game in the library within Steam go to 'Properties', and then click on 'SET LAUNCH OPTIONS...' and enter -sw. Launch the game once, it will crash but the 'prefs.prop' should be altered and have 'Windowed0' in it again after opening it with Notepad++. after this remove the -sw from the launch options)

Step 6 : Start the game, this is to check if the game runs in Windowed mode like it should. You can change the resolution to what you like, but never ever click the fullscreen option again or you will have to edit the 'prefs.prop' file once again.

Now we can make the game run in Fullscreen using Borderless Gaming

Step 7 : Install Borderless Gaming and start it (after you bought it offcourse). After that go to 'Options' and make sure it starts every time you start Windows by checking 'Run On Windows Startup'. You could also go to 'Tools' and click 'Disable Steam Hook' to make sure Steam won't tell you are in-App Bordelless Gaming all the time each time Borderless Gaming is launched.

Step 8 : Start Sam&Max in Windowed mode and in under the Applications window in Borderless Gaming you will see 'Telltale Games' appear. Click on that and then followed by the arrow pointing to the right so 'Telltale Games' will be visible under 'Favourites (automatic)'. Rightclick 'Telltale Games' in here and make sure that 'Fullscreen' and 'Auto-Maximize' are checked.

reviewText:
AUDIO: Great                                                               AESTHETIC: Quirky
MEMORABILITY: Excellent                                      WORTH: Full Price

PROS: Pretty funny series, if a little cheesy. Fragmented episodes means each story can get plenty of attention without audio and voices being overly recycled. Laugh-out-loud musical numbers. The world changes as you progress through the episodes, so there are always new details to find. I appreciate the episodic approach in this so there were no temptations to recycle dialogue.

CONS: The game does not like widescreen monitors. I had to restart my computer from the crashing twice before finding a way to get the episodes to boot in an undestructive fashion. This season was also extremely easy and offered very little challenge to neither a new point and click player nor a seasoned one.

OVERALL: Despite being absolutely no challenge, there's something to be said about a game that can make you laugh this much with such hokey humor. For some reason, the Sam & Max hasn't been dated as I expected. This duo is a lovable spin on the Good Cop, Bad Cop shtick, with both character being surprisingly complex for what seems to be a one-dimensional comedy series. I'd recommend it to anyone who is looking for a good laugh or is new to the genre.

SCORE: 9/10

reviewText:
For those who own Windows 10 and the game won't work, you can try this:
Change your screen resolution to 800X600 before run the game and it should work (at least it worked in my case).
Then turn off its fullscreen option in the game and save.
Quit the game and you can change your resolution back.
The next time you run the game, it will work properly in windowed mode.

Hopefully it could help you.

reviewText:
Sam & Max: Season One is made of 6 point'n'click adventure games, connected by the plot of hypnosis.

It's one of the first games to use episodic model of releases. And unlike many others, it used them with success, making TellTale produce more adventure games in similiar fashion. It also seems to be one of few games to be on Steam before it was cool.
Oh, and it doesn't support widescreen. Sorry folks, 2007 year and all.

Episodic model is also used in good and bad way, in a sense that you have common location and few common characters (outside of those that are unique to single episode) that keep reappearing in each episode. Sybil is most amusing, as she changes job every single episode. Such familiarity works nicely. But then, there are some negativity about it too, like, in the last episode you can suddenly pick up object that main hero refused to keep in all previous episodes.

Graphics and music have style to them, even though they are a bit weak. Both of them. Well, or not so weak.
Fine, music is nice, but more of staying in the background. And graphics are fine for cartoonish style. Lacks some good shadows though. But hey, was designed for low-end machines back then.

It's quite usual old-schoolish point'n'click by gameplay and plot, following same mindset of puzzles are the main point". Which isn't bad thing. Combined with expected humorous approach. Mature one even. You do get few hard puzzles that I am sure you would want to use at least some hints from the almighty Google. But at least you feel clever when solving some of harder ones
recommended:
when figured out Checksum puzzle.

Did I mentioned humour?
Actually
hoursPlayed: characters interaction and humour is one of the best in when it comes to "old-school by being linear and humor-based"
voteText: outdoing most of older titles.\n\nIt's a pretty nine series. Some may like it
helpfulPercent: some may not. Others will choke on rainbow bliss. From smiling too much."

reviewText:
Sam and Max is a moderately funny click adventure game that features a bunny and a dog as detective. The puzzles are simplistic, the humor is simplistic. If you are looking for profound dialogue and/or puzzles, you will not be finding it in season one.

I was not too surprised to find out that Sam and Max, like most other click adventures, have no re-playability. However, I was surprised to find how dull episode 1,2,3 is in this series. The three episodes are chock full of simple fedex delivery puzzles with esoteric solutions. Good luck solving them without a walk-through. Luckily the game does pick up it’s pace by episode 4, and the game took a turn for the best. Puzzles solutions remain esoteric, but the results of solving the puzzles can create quite amusing consequences. You also will not remain stuck at your boring ♥♥♥ apartment block which is a plus!

Telltale nailed the voice acting in this series. Intentionally annoying characters have intentionally annoying voices; you will feel like punching the screen every single time the soda poppers talk. Humor is not universal, so the jokes in this game can either strike you as “ROFL” quality or downright immature. Luckily none of the jokes are nearly as stupid or overused as the ones you find in Duke Nukem Forever.

I recommend this game solely on the basis that’s a very well polished click adventure with a unique brand of humor. It’s not immersive or challenging, but it does make for a fantastic change of pace in between long sessions of Elder Scrolls, Counter Strike, DOTA 2, etc.

reviewText:
This review is for all seasons of the Sam & Max video game series:

Being a avid cartoon fan, I would've expected something as breakneck fast and energetic as the show. What we got from one of Taletale's earlier games is a bunch of moments that feel like Sam & Max after a long day of freelance crime-solving, and it's in 3D instead of Steve Purcell's lovely hand-drawn art style.

The writing is fairly funny, but most of the experience just feels flat or shallow - probably better off buying the complete series on DVD rather than playing a game based off of it. Plus, Sam's new voice is annoying to listen to compared to the original voice actor Harvey Atkin - shame they couldn't get him for these games.

Still, even if the game, the acting, the puzzles, and the story doesn't always seem appealing, it's an enjoyable, quirky Point & Click adventure to blaze through.

The good news is that the writing improves slightly each season as well as the graphics. It's also amusing to see the same location altered due to the events of past game episodes as well as deviate to some new ones connected to the game's Main st.

7/10: worth one playthrough, not much else.

reviewText: Heh, I've played this three ways now: once when it was a monthly exclusive on GameTap, once on the Wii and finally through here. The Wii...forget about it. That console just can't handle it, and the load times are extreme. But the PC release is solid. If you've ever read the comics, watched the cartoon or played Hit The Road back in the nineties, you've probably already hit the buy button. Sam & Max manage to remain irreverent in a grown-up-cartoon genre that they largely pioneered, and even with new competition like Family Guy they haven't lost any of their charm. They also manage to get in a lot of jokes about adventure gaming, so bonus points for that.

reviewText:
Sam & Max: Season One is an episodic point and click adventure game series that adapts the classic comic series into a game.  Unsurprisingly, this is a fantastic means to adapt the comic, as nothing suits the series inane and black comedy humor so well.  The first season has plenty to do and see.  While there's nonexistent consequences for making a wrong choice, it's still pretty great to see all of the seperate choices and the dialogue as a result.

PROS:

Fantastic adaption of the comic series.
Lots of well written dialogue and jokes with some references to the original series
Original story line
6 Episodes, all about 2-3 hours apiece, so about at least 12 hours total, depending on how fast you solve the puzzles.
CONS:

Each episode requires seperate settings, so you'll have to change them upon starting up.
Sam walks everywhere, which can be annoying at times (this is fixed in the second season)
Like with any starting series, the first episode is perhaps the most flat, with the voice acting for the title characters being weirdly flat and unlike the characters. Things thankfully get under way following the next episode and from there things go off the rails as a good Sam and Max series should.
Like most adventure games, the logic can be weird at times, with some solutions requiring things you didn't know you can use.  (So i suggest keeping EVERYTHING that you can comment on in mind).  This is of course debatable since most people can probably solve it faster than others.
Each episode is technically a standalone game, so you're gonna have a lot of titles in your library if you install them all.
I got the entire three seasons for 10 bucks, so i can't say whether or not it's worth it for regular price.  I can say it's worth getting if you enjoy black comedy or are a fan of the series.  Very recommended.

reviewText: Sam and Max Season One was a great way to start of the series of course they graphic aren't up to date but then again this was released in 2007 so what can we expect the comedy is great,sarcastic,ironic,and a whole lot of fun the downsides are that there are some minor bugs and come in seperate games you have to download another thing was  that the walking is slow so getting to point a to point b and may get repetetive was but in the end the humor is good and story was interesting for people who like point and click and who are patient definitly get this game but if your a casual game play then i would recomend something like monkey island for people who dont really enjoy games like this more something like COD or CSGO then i still recomend this game because this game is hilarious and makes you enjoy it to its ful extent  but for me personally i enjoyed this game so much i give it a 9/10 because there are some bugs and kind of repetetive(barely) and and get kinda confusing I understand this is not a AAA(triple A title) but there is some repetetiveness and  trust me that repetetive parts in this game is VERY ANNOYING that so therefore it is a 9/10.

reviewText:
Don't you just love it when they bring older games available on Steam and don't bother to patch them so that they work normally by just starting the game? Not even when the community has addressed the problem to developers and Valve (many cases can be found by googling). And these are not even that old games!

Luckily the solution to get these Sam & Max games to work is simple this time: just set your screen resolution to 1028x960 or lower and the game launches fine to full screen. You can also try to be fast with Alt+Enter (to put the game in windowed mode) when you launch the game, but I found out that some of the objects and backgrounds weren't showing up properly this way.

Telltale's Sam & Max games themselves are simplified classic point-n-click adventure games and I do recommended them for their humour and easy-going gameflow.

reviewText: If you've played Back to the Future: The Game, Strong Bad's Cool Game For Attractive People, or Tales of Monkey Island, then you'll be familiar with Telltale's episodic structuring of their games.  Each episode seems to be isolated story-wise at first, but they do interconnect, and have consequences in Seasons 2 & 3.  I love visiting Bosco's Inconvience and Sybil Pandemik's office every episode, seeing what's new, dealing with Max's sociopathic attitude, and talking with the cheerful but mysterious Hugh Bliss, pushing his Prismatology cult.  Point-and-click adventure fans will love this season, and the rest too.

reviewText:
Most people who have a game from this series have Sam & Max: The Devil’s Playhouse - from bundle site sales. But a good number do not have the season 1 or 2.

This is another telltale game. So it's a point and click adventure  (for all you call of duty fanboys out there, there's very limited shooting involved in this game).

This game is fun to play through I did all the parts in one go as Freelance Police - Sam and Max make their way to determine who is the mastermind behind all the hypnotism of people of earth. In order to do so you must become a TV star, defeat Abe Lincoln, become President of the United States, spend $1 trillion dollars on special items - that is a lot to do and so little time before the planet earth become victims of always being happy and optimistic (OOOHHH NO!!!)

Another telltale game worth playing through :D

reviewText:
The First 6 Monthly Episodes of the Entire Sam & Max Trilogy. Sam & Max Save the World (Season 1) delivers the best in Point & Click Adventure Games. Season 1 revolves around various schemes to gain power by hypnotizing large amounts of people. Help Sam & Max Save the World in their first Exciting Season!

In Episode 1, A group of former child stars, known as the Soda Poppers, are found causing trouble in Sam and Max's neighborhood.

In Episode 2, Myra Stump; a television talkshow host, has taken her audience hostage. Sam and Max are called to defuse the situation.

In Episode 3, The commissioner is looking into an underground operation at Ted E. Bear Mafia's-Free Playland & Casino, but the mole he sent in has suddenly gone quiet. To find the mole, Sam & Max must infiltrate the operation and become members of the Toy Mafia themselves.

In Episode 4, Sam & Max must investigate the top man himself, the President of the United States, who has been passing inane mandates such as required hugs. Not only must the two take down the President, they may have to install their own man in his place, though Abe Lincoln may have a word or two about that.

In Episode 5, People are being hypnotized by the Internet craze, causing systems around the world to go haywire. Sam and Max must find a way to enter the virtual world and track down the heart of the Internet herself to pull the plug on her shenanigans.

And In Episode 6; The Season 1 Finale, Sam and Max must go to the moon in order to save the entire world from hypnotic enslavement.

You can get Sam & Max S1-EP1 in Sam & Max Season 1: Sam & Max Save the World can be played on the PC/Xbox 360's Xbox LIVE & Wii Consoles!

reviewText: I played this because I was curious about Telltale's older pre-Walking Dead games, and I simply bought nearly all of their games on sale. Controls similar to their more recent games, but do not expect a Walking Dead experience here. This game is not about hard decisions and emotional trauma. No, this is all about comedy, and that's awesome too. Loved every minute of it. This was my first exposure to Sam and Max, but I can't wait to play the other two seasons I've bought, and possibly even check into the cartoon and comics.

reviewText: I played Sam and Max hit the road ages ago and didn't get very far with it. However now with this internet thingy when you are bereft of the necessary deranged logic required to work out which of the myriad of items you have collected you need to use on what, you can just look it up. Unfortunately looking up a walkthrough is like eating pringles; once you pop you just can't stop. The puzzles do get annoying from time to time but the story is great and the characters are brilliant and lovable. If you are interested in point and click games then this is a must.

reviewText:
This was a nice change to play from what Telltale puts out these days. Their old games focus more on a linear story, point and click adventure. Rather than having choices that changes the outcome of the game. The challenge here is to gather things and use logic(most of the time…) to find out what items and dialogue triggers what. and you have to do a lot or going back and forth between locations in the game.

I had to resort to guides online multiple times, at first I thought I was getting stupid, but then I realized I’ve gotten spoiled by newer games. In the end it kinda took me back, and I rather enjoyed playing through it.

I had NO knowledge or prior experience with Sam & Max apart from the Poker games from Telltale, so the terrible jokes(which I like…), references and the way they solve crime blew me away. Not recommended if you are after a “immersive and realistic” type of game.

As for the technical aspect, this is an old game. The engine is outdated and only supports 3 resolutions(at least it did for me, 1024x768 was the highest it would go), this game also ran at 40-50fps max. But it was nothing I really didn’t expect from a game this old, it still played nicely. But if you are running Windows 10 however, it seems like you aren’t gonna be able to play. The support section is filled with those complaints.

So all in all, a fun game series which takes me back, is packed with terrible jokes and references. And doesn’t cost much compared to what you get out of it.(If you aren’t on Win10 that is, then don’t bother…) So I recommend it a lot.

reviewText: Short, small-scale comedy point-and-click. It takes between an hour and two-and-a-half hours per episode as the episodes become more complex and the puzzles more abstract. I enjoyed it thoroughly, though. A word of warning: it may look child-friendly, but at times it is not, and the writing doesn't feel like it was ever intended to be.

reviewText: I bought this game (starting with season 1) because i remember playing S&M first on floppy disks, then eventually on CD-ROM with Sam & Max: Hit the Road. I loved those games, and they are some of my favorites from that era of gaming. These games completely live up to that sense of adventure and whimsey. Never have i played a reboot of a series that so accurately captured the look and feel of the original, while adding new content to the series. If you were a fan of the games, or at least the point&click genre, from that time.. do yourself and favor and pick up this game. Also, i am a Windows 10 Pro x64 user, and have had no troubles running the game. Not sure what others' issues are, but i put the game's executable in compatibility mode with Vista and everything runs as smooth as hot butter running down Max's supple, yet firm, back.

reviewText:
This was a nice change to play from what Telltale puts out these days. Their old games focus more on a linear story, point and click adventure. Rather than having choices that changes the outcome of the game. The challenge here is to gather things and use logic(most of the time…) to find out what items and dialogue triggers what. and you have to do a lot or going back and forth between locations in the game.

I had to resort to guides online multiple times, at first I thought I was getting stupid, but then I realized I’ve gotten spoiled by newer games. In the end it kinda took me back, and I rather enjoyed playing through it.

I had NO knowledge or prior experience with Sam & Max apart from the Poker games from Telltale, so the terrible jokes(which I like…), references and the way they solve crime blew me away. Not recommended if you are after a “immersive and realistic” type of game.

As for the technical aspect, this is an old game. The engine is outdated and only supports 3 resolutions(at least it did for me, 1024x768 was the highest it would go), this game also ran at 40-50fps max. But it was nothing I really didn’t expect from a game this old, it still played nicely. But if you are running Windows 10 however, it seems like you aren’t gonna be able to play. The support section is filled with those complaints.

So all in all, a fun game series which takes me back, is packed with terrible jokes and references. And doesn’t cost much compared to what you get out of it.(If you aren’t on Win10 that is, then don’t bother…) So I recommend it a lot.
